case_name: Noor Khan v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Noor Khan and nine others were tried before the Additional Sessions Judge, Sirohi for offences of rioting, being members of an unlawful assembly, and causing death of Pratap on September 29, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Noor Khan, resident of Kuchaman in the State of Rajasthan, and nine others were tried before the Additional Sessions judge, Sirohi in the State of Rajasthan for offences of rioting and being members of an unlawful assembly and causing in furtherance of their common object death of one Pratap, at about 2-30 p. m. on September 29, 1960 and serious injuries to four others on the same occasion.

facts.text: Noor Khan was charged with the substantive offence of causing the death of Pratap by gunshot injuries.

anchor.surface_text: Noor Khan was also charged for the substantive offence of causing the death of Pratap by gunshot injuries.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted all accused.

anchor.surface_text: The .Sessions Judge acquitted all the persons accused. at the trial.

facts.text: In State appeal, Rajasthan High Court set aside acquittal of Noor Khan and convicted him under s.302 IPC, sentenced to life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal by the State, the High Court of Rajasthan set aside the order of acquittal in favour of Noor Khan and convicted Noor Khan for causing the death of Pratap by firing a muzzle-loading gun and causing him fatal injury and thereby committing an offence punishable under s. 302 Indian Penal Code and sentenced him to suffer imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 9 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 9, 1962 of the -Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Criminal Appeal No. 407 of 1961.

facts.text: Disputes between Noor Khan and Pratap and his brothers about a well in village Mundara.

anchor.surface_text: There were disputes between Noor Khan on the one hand and Pratap and his brothers on the other about a well in village Mundara. Noor Khan claimed to have purchased a half share in the well whereas Pratap and his brothers claimed the well to be their exclusive property, and there were several court proceedings about this dispute.

facts.text: On September 29, 1960 at about 2:00 p.m., Noor Khan accompanied by his father Samdu Khan and eight others went to Pratap's field containing the disputed well.

anchor.surface_text: It was the case for the prosecution that on September 29, 1960 at about 2-00 p.m. Noor Khan accompanied by his father Samdu Khan and eight others went to Prataps. field  in which there was a farm, a house, a stable and the disputed well  and called upon Pratap to deliver possession of the well

facts.text: Samdu Khan fired a muzzle-loading gun at Ganesh (brother of Pratap) but missed.

anchor.surface_text: and on the latter declining to do so, Samdu Khan fired a muzzle-loading gun at Ganesh--brother of Pratap-but missed him.

facts.text: Noor Khan fired at Pratap and killed him instantaneously.

anchor.surface_text: Noor Khan then fired at Pratap and killed him instantaneously.

facts.text: Other members of Noor Khan's party beat Ganesh, Prabhu, Mohan and Gulab (brothers of Pratap) with sticks and other weapons causing injuries.

anchor.surface_text: The other members of the party of Noor Khan at the instigation of Samdu Khan thereafter beat Ganesh, Prabhu, Mohan and Gulab--brothers of Pratap-with sticks and other weapons and caused them injuries.

facts.text: Ganesh lodged complaint against 15 persons including Noor Khan and Samdu Khan at police station Bali.

anchor.surface_text: After the assailants retired, Ganesh lodged a complaint against 15 persons including Noor Khan an.d Samdu Khan at the police station, Bali.

facts.text: Ten accused arrested and tried before Sessions Court, Sirohi.

anchor.surface_text: Ten out of those who were named in the complaint were arrested and tried before the Court of Session, Sirohi.

facts.text: Pratap died on September 29, 1960 from gunshot injury; post-mortem by Dr. Mehta showed lacerated left lung.

anchor.surface_text: Pratap died on September 29, 1960 as a result of gun- shot injury. The testimony of Dr. Mehta who performed the post-mortem examination on the dead body of Pratap discloses beside the wound of entry that the left lung of the victim was lacerated with pieces of metal.

facts.text: Dr. Mehta found injuries on Prabhu (two contusions, one incised), Ganesh (three contusions), Mohan (one contusion), Gulab (swelling), about 48 hours old on October 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Mehta found on the body of witness Prabhu two contusions and an incised injury, on the body of Ganesh three contusions, on Mohan one contusion and on Gulab a swelling and in the view of Dr. Mehta the injuries were, at the time when he examined the injured persons on October 1, 1960, about 48 hours old.

facts.text: Eyewitnesses Prabhu, Ganesh, Mohan, Gulab deposed Noor Khan caused fatal injury to Pratap by gun.

anchor.surface_text: Prabhu, Ganesh, Mohan and Gulab were examined as witnesses for the prosecution, and they deposed that Noor Khan had caused the fatal injury to Pratap by firing a muzzle-loading gun at him, and that they were injured in the same incident by the members of Noor Khans party.

facts.text: Story corroborated by female witnesses Bhanwari and Mathura.

anchor.surface_text: This story was further corroborated by two female witnesses, Bhanwari and Mathura.

facts.text: High Court held fatal injury caused by appellant Noor Khan with gun from about 4 ft.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon the testimony of Mst. Bhanwari supported by the testimony of Mohan Singh and Mst. Mathura the High Court held that the fatal injury to. Pratap was caused by the appellant with a gun fired from a distance of about 4 ft. from the body of Pratap.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted holding prosecution story unreliable due to lack of independent witnesses, alterations, false involvement.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge acquitted all the accused holding that the story that there was an unlawful assembly of ten or more persons who went to the well and caused the death of Pratap was not reliable, for in his view the prosecution had failed to lead evidence of independent witnesses and alterations were made in the story of the prosecution from time to time and certain persons were falsely involved.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal, upheld High Court conviction.

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal with special leave we do not think that we would be justified in interfering with the conclusion of the High Court especially when our attention has not been invited to any substantial infirmity in the reasoning of that Court.

facts.text: Investigating officer Hari Singh made jottings, not detailed statements; head-constable Kapuraram prepared statements from jottings without witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: the investigating officer Hari Singh who stated that he had made jottings or notes of the statements of witnesses, and that he did not record detailed statements in the course of the investigation, and that from these jottings head-constable Kapuraram prepared the statements of the witnesses  supplied at the trial to the accused

facts.text: No prejudice caused to accused by not supplying true s.161 statements.

anchor.surface_text: we are unable to hold that the trial was illegal. No attempt appears to have been made by the Trial Court to scrutinize the diary of sub- inspector Hari Singh, nor was any objection raised in the High Court that by reason of the failure to make the notes or the jottings available to the accused any prejudice was caused.

facts.text: Presence of injuries on four eyewitnesses corroborates their presence at scene.

anchor.surface_text: The injuries on these four persons strongly corroborate their story that at the time of the assault made on Pratap at about 2-00 p.m. on September 29, 1960 they were present.

facts.text: Gun fired from close range, about 4 ft., evidenced by charring and blackening.

anchor.surface_text: It appears however from the appearance of the injury and especially the charring and blackening of the wound of entry that the barrel of the gun could not have been at a distance exceeding 3 or 4 ft.

facts.text: Enmity between parties, some persons falsely named in FIR.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court in appeal by the State held that notwithstanding the infirmities in the prosecution case that in the first information, names of certain persons who were not present at the scene of occurrence were given by the complainant Ganesh on account of enmity

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by Shah J. on August 19, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: August 19, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.

CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 9 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 9, 1962 of the -Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Criminal Appeal No. 407 of 1961.

In appeal by the State, the High Court of Rajasthan set aside the order of acquittal in favour of Noor Khan and convicted Noor Khan for causing the death of Pratap by firing a muzzle-loading gun and causing him fatal injury and thereby committing an offence punishable under s. 302 Indian Penal Code and sentenced him to suffer imprisonment for life.

concepts.interpretation: Conviction for causing death by firing gun upheld as murder punishable under s.302 IPC.

for offences of rioting and being members of an unlawful assembly

issues.text: Whether the High Court had the power to review the evidence and reverse the order of acquittal passed by the Sessions Judge?

anchor.surface_text: The appeal before the High Court was one against an order of acquittal. But as explained by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Sheo Swarup and others v. King Emperor 1  ss, 417, 418 and 423 of the Code give to the High Court full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded, and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed.

issues.text: Whether the testimony of the eyewitnesses (Ganesh, Prabhu, Mohan, Gulab, Bhanwari, Mathura) is reliable despite discrepancies in the first information report, estimates of distance, and sequence of firing?

anchor.surface_text: Prabhu, Ganesh, Mohan and Gulab were examined as witnesses for the prosecution, and they deposed that Noor Khan had caused the fatal injury to Pratap by firing a muzzle-loading gun at him, and that they were injured in the same incident by the members of Noor Khans party. The injuries on these four persons strongly corroborate their story that at the time of the assault made on Pratap at about 2-00 p.m. on September 29, 1960 they were present.

issues.text: Whether Noor Khan caused the fatal gunshot injury to Pratap, constituting murder under Section 302 IPC?

anchor.surface_text: In appeal by the State, the High Court of Rajasthan set aside the order of acquittal in favour of Noor Khan and convicted Noor Khan for causing the death of Pratap by firing a muzzle-loading gun and causing him fatal injury and thereby committing an offence punishable under s. 302 Indian Penal Code and sentenced him to suffer imprisonment for life.

issues.text: Whether the failure of the investigating officer to supply genuine copies of statements recorded under Section 161 CrPC (instead providing statements prepared from jottings by head-constable in absence of witnesses, and destroying original jottings) vitiates the trial under Section 537 CrPC?
Whether the accused was prejudiced by the irregularity in the supply of police statements under Sections 161, 173, and 207A CrPC, warranting reversal of conviction?

arguments.claim: Prosecution story unreliable due to lack of independent witnesses, alterations in story, and false involvement of persons due to enmity warranting acquittal of all accused

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge acquitted all the accused holding that the story that there was an unlawful assembly of ten or more persons who went to the well and caused the death of Pratap was not reliable, for in his view the prosecution had failed to lead evidence of independent witnesses and alterations were made in the story of the prosecution from time to time and certain persons were falsely involved.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Prabhu Singh s o Guman Singh who was number a member of the family and who claimed to be an eye-witness to the assault on Pratap and others was, foun

arguments.court_reasoning: Injuries on eyewitnesses corroborate presence beyond reasonable doubt; discrepancies minor and explained; High Court reviewed evidence properly considering presumption of innocence

arguments.claim: High Court has full power under ss.417,418,423 CrPC to review evidence at large and reverse acquittal

anchor.surface_text: The appeal before the High Court was one against an order of acquittal. But as explained by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Sheo Swarup and others v. King Emperor 1  ss, 417, 418 and 423 of the Code give to the High Court full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded, and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed.

arguments.claim: Eyewitness testimony reliable despite no independent witnesses because injuries corroborate presence at scene

anchor.surface_text: The injuries on these four persons strongly corroborate their story that at the time of the assault made on Pratap at about 2-00 p.m. on September 29, 1960 they were present. This story was further corroborated by two female witnesses, Bhanwari and Mathura.

arguments.claim: Infirmities in FIR (false names due to enmity, discrepancies in firing sequence) do not affect substantial prosecution case

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in appeal by the State held that notwithstanding the infirmities in the prosecution case that in the first information, names of certain persons who were not present at the scene of occurrence were given by the complainant Ganesh on account of enmity and that there were discrepancies between the statements of the eye witnesses at the trial and the first information on the question as to who, out of the two persons Samdu Khan and the appellant Noor Khan, fired first, the substantial case of the prosecution remained unaffected thereby

court_response_anchor.surface_text: and the High Court was right in observing that the discrepancies between those statements and the evidence given by the witnesses at the trial would n

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court analysis upheld; false names only discredit Ganesh whose testimony discarded; others consistent

arguments.claim: Fatal injury caused by Noor Khan firing gun from close range (~4 ft), consistent with medical evidence

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon the testimony of Mst. Bhanwari supported by the testimony of Mohan Singh and Mst. Mathura the High Court held that the fatal injury to. Pratap was caused by the appellant with a gun fired from a distance of about 4 ft. from the body of Pratap.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the assaulting party were at the time of the assault somewhere near the Peepal tree, the situation of which is definitely established by reliable evi

arguments.court_reasoning: Charring/blackening and topography (peepal tree positions) confirm close range despite witness estimates

arguments.claim: Sessions Judge erred by not appreciating significance of injuries on four eyewitnesses as corroboration of presence

anchor.surface_text: It may be observed that. in declining to accept the testimony of the witnesses who claim to have seen the assault, the Sessions Judge did not appreciate the full significance of the very important circumstance that on the person of the four eye-witnesses there were injuries which on the medical evidence must have been caused at or about the time when the fatal assault was made upon Pratap.

arguments.claim: Discrepancy in number of shots (one injury but two guns) does not make story improbable

anchor.surface_text: the Sessions Judge did not found his conclusion upon the demeanour of the witnesses, except possibly of Ganesh. He entered upon a review of the evidence and rested his conclusion primarily upon four circumstances that the persons who were proved not to be present at the time of the commission of the offence were sought to be involved in the commission of the offence that the evidence showed that only one shot was fired even though the witnesses deposed that both Samdu Khan and Noor Khan were armed with muzzle-loading guns

arguments.court_reasoning: Samdu fired at Ganesh and missed; possible no injury from miss

arguments.claim: Witness estimates of firing distance unreliable for illiterate villagers; topography confirms close range

anchor.surface_text: that the distance from which the gun which caused the fatal injury to Pratap was fired was estimated by the witnesses at not, less than 20 ft, whereas Dr. Mehta deposed that the gun was fired from a distance of only 4 ft. and that the accused Noor Khan and others were deprived of the benefit of having access to the police statements recorded under s. 161 Code of Criminal Procedure.

arguments.court_reasoning: Fixed positions (peepal tree, ora) and rough sketch show ~4ft; estimates in 'poundas' faulty

arguments.claim: Failure to supply genuine s.161 statements (jottings destroyed, fake prepared by head-constable) vitiates trial

anchor.surface_text: But the most important defect in the trial which, it was urged by Mr. Purshottam appearing on behalf of the appellant, vitiates the order of conviction is that the accused persons were deprived of the right to obtain and use copies of the statements made by the witnesses before the investigating officer Hari Singh

arguments.court_reasoning: s.537 CrPC cures irregularities unless prejudice shown; no objection raised earlier, no prejudice to accused demonstrated

arguments.claim: s.161 CrPC mandates recording and supplying statements; deprivation is valuable right loss vitiating trial

anchor.surface_text: But it was urged that under s. 161 Criminal Procedure Code it is obligatory upon an investigating officer to record the statements of witnesses examined by him and if those statements are not made available to the accused at the trial, a valuable right which the Legislature has ensured in the interest of a satisfactory trial of the case is lost to the accused, and the trial must on that account alone be regarded as vitiated.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ry unsatisfactory that the numberes, or .the jottings as they are 35--2 8. C.India/64 called, of the statements made by the witnesses before Hari Sing

arguments.court_reasoning: Not mandatory to record; if recorded, copies supplied; but s.537 applies, prejudice required

arguments.claim: Irregularity in s.161/173/207A supply does not vitiate unless prejudice; s.537 curative
No prejudice caused by s.161 irregularity as no objection raised timely, contradictions minor
arguments.court_reasoning: Contradictions on peripheral matters (false names, non-appellant acts); core testimony consistent

arguments.claim: High Court conviction under s.302 IPC proper; no interference warranted

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal with special leave we do not think that we would be justified in interfering with the conclusion of the High Court especially when our attention has not been invited to any substantial infirmity in the reasoning of that Court.

holdings.text: Sections 417, 418 and 423 of the Code give to the High Court full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded, and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed.

anchor.surface_text: But as explained by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Sheo Swarup and others v. King Emperor 1  ss, 417, 418 and 423 of the Code give to the High Court full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded, and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying precedent from Sheo Swarup v. King Emperor; High Court must consider trial judge's views, presumption of innocence, benefit of doubt, but has full review power.

holdings.text: The presence of the four injured persons Ganesh, Prabhu, Mohan and Gulab at the scene of offence is assured by the evidence of injuries, and must, as the High Court observed, be regarded as established beyond reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: The presence of the four injured persons Ganesh, Prabhu, Mohan and Gulab at the scene of offence is assured by the evidence of injuries, and must, as the High Court observed, be regarded as established beyond reasonable doubt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Medical evidence of contemporaneous injuries corroborates eyewitness presence; improbable they were injured elsewhere and conspired; Sessions Judge failed to appreciate this.

holdings.text: Noor Khan caused the fatal gunshot injury to Pratap by firing a muzzle-loading gun from close range of about 4 feet, constituting murder under s.302 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon the testimony of Mst. Bhanwari supported by the testimony of Mohan Singh and Mst. Mathura the High Court held that the fatal injury to. Pratap was caused by the appellant with a gun fired from a distance of about 4 ft. from the body of Pratap.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eyewitness testimony corroborated by medical evidence (charring, blackening, single entry point) and topography (peepal tree positions); witness distance estimates unreliable for illiterate villagers.

holdings.text: Section 161(3) CrPC does not mandate police officer to reduce witness statements to writing; if done, separate record required and copies supplied; failure does not vitiate trial per se.

anchor.surface_text: Section 161 3 does not require a police- officer to record in writing the statements of witnesses examined by him in the course of the investigation, but if he does record in writing any such statements, he is obliged to make copies of those statements available to the accused

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation: oral examination authorized; writing optional but regulated; object to inform accused of case; cites ss.161,162,173,207A.

holdings.text: Irregularity in supplying non-genuine s.161 statements (prepared from jottings without witnesses, originals destroyed) does not vitiate trial under s.537 CrPC unless prejudice or failure of justice shown.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.537 curative unless occasions failure of justice; no timely objection, no scrutiny of diary, contradictions peripheral (false names, non-core acts); precedents Narayan Rao, Pulukuri Kottaya.

holdings.text: No prejudice caused to accused by s.161 irregularity warranting reversal of conviction.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No objection raised earlier; contradictions minor and not affecting core testimony on appellant's guilt; evidence independently reliable; s.537 explanation considers timely objection.

holdings.text: Supreme Court will not interfere with High Court conclusion upholding conviction under s.302 IPC absent substantial infirmity in reasoning.

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal with special leave we do not think that we would be justified in interfering with the conclusion of the High Court especially when our attention has not been invited to any substantial infirmity in the reasoning of that Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.136 special leave appeal limited; High Court reasoning sound on evidence review and procedural issue.

precedents.citation: Sheo Swarup and others v. King Emperor 1

anchor.surface_text: Sheo Swarup and others v. King Emperor 1  ss, 417, 418 and 423 of the Code give to the High Court full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was rounded, and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed.

precedents.cited_proposition: ss. 417, 418 and 423 of the Code give to the High Court full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded, and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed
precedents.cited_holding: High Court has full power to review evidence in appeal against acquittal and reverse it, but must give weight to trial judge's views, presumption of innocence, etc.

anchor.surface_text: I. L.R. 61 I.A. 398. Gulab at the scene of offence is assured by the evidence of injuries, and must, as the High Court observed, be regarded as established beyond reasonable doubt. The Sessions Judge did not found his conclusion upon the demeanour of the witnesses,

precedents.cited_proposition: Principles for appellate court in appeals against acquittal

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant relying upon the two judgments of the Nagpur High Court in Baliram Emperor 1  and Maganlal v. Emperor 2  submitted that omission to supply copies of the statements recorded under s. 161 is repugnant to the fundamental rules of practice necessary for the due protection of prisoners and the safe administration of justice,

precedents.cited_proposition: omission to supply copies of statements under s. 161 repugnant to fundamental rules, deprives accused of statutory rights

anchor.surface_text: I.L.R. 1945 Nag. 151. I.L.R. 1946 Nag. 126. not correctly interpret ss. 161 and 162 Code of Criminal Procedure. In a later case, the Nagpur High Court in Maroti Mahagoo v. Emperor 1  held that though the right which is given to the accused under s. 162 Code of Criminal Procedure to use the previous statements made to the police for the purpose of contradicting a witness is a valuable right,

Baliram Emperor 1  and Maganlal v. Emperor 2  submitted that omission to supply copies of the statements recorded under s. 161 is repugnant to the fundamental rules of practice necessary for the due protection of prisoners and the safe administration of justice, and where the accused was deprived of his statutory rights of cross-examination and thereby denied the opportunity of effectively destroying the testimony of prosecution witnesses the evidence of such witnesses whose statements have not been supplied to the accused is inadmissible at the trial.

precedents.cited_proposition: omission to supply copies under s. 161 makes evidence inadmissible

anchor.surface_text: I.L.R. 1946 Nag. 126. not correctly interpret ss. 161 and 162 Code of Criminal Procedure. In a later case, the Nagpur High Court in Maroti Mahagoo v. Emperor 1  held that though the right which is given to the accused under s. 162 Code of Criminal Procedure to use the previous statements made to the police for the purpose of contradicting a witness is a valuable right,

the Nagpur High Court in Maroti Mahagoo v. Emperor 1  held that though the right which is given to the accused under s. 162 Code of Criminal Procedure to use the previous statements made to the police for the purpose of contradicting a witness is a valuable right, and where the omission to give copies to the accused is proved to have caused prejudice to the accused, the testimony of such witness must be received with extreme caution and the Court would be entitled in a suitable case even to ignore altogether such evidence, but the evidence is not inadmissible and every case must be decided on its own facts.

precedents.cited_proposition: right under s.162 valuable; omission causing prejudice leads to caution in receiving evidence, may ignore, but not inadmissible; decide on facts
precedents.cited_holding: evidence not inadmissible despite failure to supply statements if no prejudice

anchor.surface_text: I.L.R. 1948 Nag. 110. A.I.R. 1957 S.C.737. upon police officers concerned and Magistrates before whom such proceedings are brought, to see that all the documents, necessary to give the accused persons all the information for the proper conduct of their defence, are furnished.

precedents.citation: Narayan Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh 2

anchor.surface_text: A.I.R. 1957 S.C.737. and it was held that failure to comply with the provisions of s. 173 (4) and s. 207A (3) is merely an irregularity which does not affect the validity of the trial.

precedents.case_name: Narayan Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: failure to comply with ss.173(4) and 207A(3) is irregularity not vitiating trial
precedents.cited_holding: provisions directory, not mandatory; no automatic vitiation unless prejudice shown

anchor.surface_text: I.L.R. 1948 Nag. 110. A.I.R. 1957 S.C.737. upon police officers concerned and Magistrates before whom such proceedings are brought, to see that all the documents, necessary to give the accused persons all the information for the proper conduct of their defence, are furnished. . . . But we are not prepared to hold that non-compliance with those provisions has, necessarily, the result of vitiating those proceedings and subsequent trial.

precedents.case_name: Narayan Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: The Court in that case relied upon the observations made by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Pulukuri Kotayya v. Emperor 1  to the effect that when a trial is conducted in a manner different from that prescribed by the Code, the trial is bad, and no question of curing an irregularity arises,

precedents.cited_proposition: if trial conducted substantially as per Code, irregularities curable under s.537 unless failure of justice
precedents.cited_holding: valuable right under s.162; failure to supply copies not automatically illegal, consider prejudice

anchor.surface_text: L.R, 74 I.A. 65. comprehensive provisions of the Code. In dealing with result of failure to supply copies of statements recorded under s. 161 Code of Criminal Procedure, the Judicial Committee observed in Pulukuri Kotayyas case 1  The right given to an accused person by this section is a very valuable one and often provides important material for cross examination of the prosecution witnesses.

Courts in India have always regarded any breach of the proviso to s. 162 as matter of gravity. I.R. 1945 Nag. 1 where the record of statements made by witnesses had been destroyed, and 53 All. 458, where the Court had refused to supply to the accused copies of statements made by witnesses to the police, afford instances in which failure to comply with the provisions of s. 162 have led to the conviction being quashed.

precedents.cited_proposition: breach of s.162 proviso grave; destruction of statements led to quashing conviction

anchor.surface_text: I.R. 1945 Nag. 1 where the record of statements made by witnesses had been destroyed, and 53 All. 458, where the Court had refused to supply to the accused copies of statements made by witnesses to the police, afford instances in which failure to comply with the provisions of s. 162 have led to the conviction being quashed.

precedents.cited_proposition: refusal to supply statements led to quashing conviction
